Cramton, Ockenfels, and Stoft (2015) make an analogous argument in the form of a numerical example indicating that committing to a price tends to be less risky than quantity targets. Thus, according to this reasoning, equity transfers under cap-and-trade would have to be larger than equity transfers under a uniform price because of the increased risk imposed by caps. In a separate argument, they also indicate that choosing a particular green-fund equity-payment formula to encourage participation in a uniform price regime can itself be reduced from a seemingly n-dimensional problem to a one-dimensional focal problem.
